ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to use different techniques to write non-fiction and other magazine-style essays. How to closely read essays for craft.
I feel like I became a much better reader and writer through this class. We did a deep dive into various published articles.
How to give good constructive feedback, read for an author's voice and style, and develop my own voice.
I got accustomed to producing essays quickly, and I got better at evaluating writing and providing constructive feedback on it.
I developed a much more precise writing style. I got to explore my own voice in my writing, and through reading lots of essays, gained critical reading skills to help improve my own work.

This course introduced me to four different genres of writing, tons of famous writers and their work for me to continue exploring after this class, a basic knowledge of the main publications in the writing world, and a wide assortment of writing techniques for each genre.
Exploring different genres of nonfiction writing, getting comfortable with your voice as a writer

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strength of the course was in the quality of the readings selected and in the specificity of the feedback received. I cannot think of any particular weaknesses at this time.

I really appreciated the feedback process in which we submitted drafts, received feedback, and resubmitted a final draft. I think sometimes the class was a little redundant in going over the readings and talking about technical terms.
This course is great for variety and for forcing you to read lots of different voices all attempting to achieve the same thing-- however, we sometimes did not get to discuss all of the readings.

It's a solid course for practicing your writing skills and forcing you to learn to write quickly, but doesn't offer too much new knowledge beyond that. I think spending more time working on essay drafts in and out of class and less time on breaking down the readings would be very helpful.
I didn't think this course had any weaknesses. The layout is pretty simple: read essays, discuss essays, write essays. It worked really well.

This class is a wonderful introduction to the world of writing for those interested in ever modeling the big-name publications. We got exposed to the work of a variety of writers in a all four genres. With that said, I wish we spent more time discussing where the writers e studied could have improved their pieces. Although this may not have been intended, It felt sometimes as though we were to study the works of these acclaimed writers as the golden standard when writing is an extremely subjective field.
I absolutely loved Pam and the class in general. Very interesting pieces we got to read, and I loved every assignment. The amount of feedback we got in each draft was super helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The success was the seminar format itself. Having a small class is great over Zoom. In general, I advocate for shorter classes on Zoom, so maybe it would have been better suited to be an hour long this year.
Professor Newton fostered a great environment which felt very inclusive and open.
I thought that the Zoom discussions went pretty smoothly. Although small seminar classes are undoubtedly better in person, this format definitely still worked.
I would've loved to have this class in person. While this class was all around great for a Zoom seminar, being in person would elevated it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I think this is an amazing introductory writing course and the prompts are incredibly engaging. I think most students that enjoy writing will enjoy English 120.
Yes!
I would recommend this course to beginning writers, as it provides a solid introduction to creative nonfiction.

I would recommend this course. Since everyone has a writing requirement, everyone has a reason to take it. Taking this class is a great way to generally improve as a writer, and it's fun. We got to read a variety of different essays and write about topics that were interesting to us. It is a staple Yale class, and there is good reason.

Yes! This course forced me to produce a lot of writing in one semester, but I improved so much as a result.I recommend it for anyone looking to get a first inside look into writing for publications and learning how to write on a technical level. You'll find a support system of other students who want to be writers.
YES!! Take 120 with Pam if you can :)

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
N/A
